results.title: Smile of Buddha
results.creator_credit: Yves Gautier, UNICEF and Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais
results.brief_description: The sparrows of Saigon of the opening song refer to the thousands of homeless and injured children of this city, who are both victims of the war or whose already miserable condition the war has worsened. Orphanages and hospitals provide some of these children with food and care. Various nurses and organisers in these places, speak about the children, their work, and children are shown as they talk, play or are treated.

results.title: Smile for auntie
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A gently wicked satiric animated look at an aunt’s attempt to make baby smile. About the strange behaviour adults indulge in when attempting to communicate with, and relate to an infant. The aunt is seen from a child’s eye view. From the book written and illustrated by Diane Paterson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Smash palace
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, New Zealand Film Commission and Aardvark Films
results.brief_description: Smash Palace is a remarkable drama about a marital breakup which erupts into an impulsive kidnapping of a child by the father, and a totally credible escalation to the brink of tragedy. Bruno Lawrence and Anna Jemison play the estranged couple in strong performances. Filmed amongst a vast junk-yard of cars, Donaldson’s direction is economical and enthralling, capturing the tension that goes beneath the surface of this all too real drama.

results.title: Smart footwork
results.creator_credit: Toby Carpenter, Palfreeman Film Productions and Renown Pictures
results.brief_description: It is said that a man spends half of his life in his shoes, yet gives them less thought than any other article of apparel. Here in this film we watch the process of manufacture of footwear in a British factory, starting with the evil-smelling tannery where the hides are treated, and ending wiht someone’s feet in a smart pair of finished shoes. The film shows also examples of footwear worn as long ago as the 15th century, and watch master craftsmen at work on hand-made shoes.

results.title: Smallpox: merciless traveller
results.creator_credit: Vaclav Bedrich, World Health Organisation and Czechoslovak Film Studios
results.brief_description: This animated film deals with the history of smallpox throughout the ages. Shows how it has ravaged the world from the time of the Pharoahs, the discovery of a vaccine by Edward Jenner and his fight to have it recognised by international medical authorities and how the smallpox problem is being dealt with in the present day.

results.title: Small world = Le Monde est petit
results.creator_credit: Jacques Valentin, Unesco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Children from some forty countries were asked to give their interpretation in drawings of the world from pre-history to the year 3000 AD. This film, made within the framework of UNESCO’s project for the mutual understanding of Orient and Occident, shows that the imagination of children knows no frontiers.

results.title: Small treasures
results.brief_description: Based on autobiographical experience, Small Treasures is about the still birth of a child. Written in a diary form, it follows an ordinary pregnancy through to its devastating conclusion. Beautifully made and hand coloured this film won best short at the Venice Film Festival.
results.description: Based on autobiographical experience, Small Treasures is about the still birth of a child. Written in a diary form, it follows an ordinary pregnancy through to its devastating conclusion. Beautifully made and hand coloured this film won best short at the Venice Film Festival.
